user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimerGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_TimerGetInfo(osal_id_t timer_id, OS_timer_prop_t *timer_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *           record;
    int32                          return_code;
    osal_objtype_t                 objtype;
    OS_object_token_t              token;
    OS_timecb_internal_record_t *  timecb;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *timebase;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(timer_prop);

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    memset(timer_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_timer_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, timer_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_timecb_table, token);
        timecb   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timecb_table, token);
        timebase = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, timecb->timebase_token);

        strncpy(timer_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(timer_prop->name) - 1);
        timer_prop->creator       = record->creator;
        timer_prop->interval_time = (uint32)timecb->interval_time;
        timer_prop->accuracy      = timebase->accuracy_usec;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimerGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
static inline osal_objtype_t OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(osal_id_t id)
{
    return (OS_ObjectIdToInteger(id) >> OS_OBJECT_TYPE_SHIFT);
}
...
osal_id_t OS_TaskGetId_Impl(void)
{
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t self_record;

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    self_record.opaque_arg = pthread_getspecific(POSIX_GlobalVars.ThreadKey);

    return self_record.id;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_timecb_table
...
OS_timecb_internal_record_t OS_timecb_table[OS_MAX_TIMERS]
...
extern OS_timebase_internal_record_t OS_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
typedef struct
{
    char              timer_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    uint32            flags;
    OS_object_token_t timebase_token;
    osal_id_t         prev_cb;
    osal_id_t         next_cb;
    uint32            backlog_resets;
    int32             wait_time;
    int32             interval_time;
    OS_ArgCallback_t  callback_ptr;
    void *            callback_arg;
} OS_timecb_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char           timebase_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    OS_TimerSync_t external_sync;
    uint32         accuracy_usec;
    osal_id_t      first_cb;
    uint32         freerun_time;
    uint32         nominal_start_time;
    uint32         nominal_interval_time;
} OS_timebase_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
    uint32    start_time;
    uint32    interval_time;
    uint32    accuracy;
} OS_timer_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_objtype_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB 0x09
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE 0x08
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE (-35)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No compiler language extensions were detected in the provided code. Specific points examined and why they do not require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2:

- static inline (OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl): The inline keyword is standard (C99 and later). This is not a compiler extension.
- pthread_getspecific usage in OS_TaskGetId_Impl: This is a POSIX library call, not a language extension.
- Union member access (OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t self_record; assigning opaque_arg then returning id): Accessing different union members can be implementation-defined behavior but is not a compiler language extension (and Rule 1.2 requires reporting explicit compiler extensions documented as such).
- Macros (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, etc.): These are preprocessor constructs using standard C preprocessor behavior, not compiler-specific extensions.
- Pointer/array/indexing operations, bit-shifts, casts (e.g., (uint32)timecb->interval_time), memset, strncpy: All standard C operations and library functions, not extensions.
- No use of known compiler-specific tokens or language extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ...; }) GNU extensions, nested functions, _Pragma with compiler-specific usages, or other vendor-specific keywords were present.

Given the above, there are no fragments that explicitly rely on compiler-documented language extensions, so nothing is reported for further investigation under Rule 1.2.
